excuse.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to forgive someone for doing something that is not seriously wrong, such as being rude or careless
excuse.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: I’ll excuse you this time, but don’t be late again.
Smith can be excused for his lack of interest in the course  (=his lack of interest is reasonable).
Please excuse me for being so late today.
excuse.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In informal situations, people often say sorry about …, sorry for doing ...  or sorry I … rather than asking someone to excuse something:
Sorry for being so late, or Sorry I’m so late.
excuse.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to allow someone not to do something that they are supposed to do
excuse.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Can I be excused from swimming today? I have a cold.
excuse.translation[0].definitions[1].not: Excuse is usually passive in this meaning
excuse.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to be or give a good reason for someone’s careless or offensive behaviour
excuse.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Nothing can excuse that kind of rudeness.
excuse.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to give someone permission to leave a place
excuse.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: May I please be excused from the table?
excuse.translation[0].definitions[3].not: Excuse is usually passive in this meaning
excuse.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a reason that you give to explain careless or offensive behaviour
excuse.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I’m tired of listening to his excuses.
What’s your excuse for being late this time?
excuse.translation[1].definitions[1].def: a reason that you invent to explain an action and to hide your real intentions
excuse.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: I need an excuse to call her.
The conference is just an excuse for a holiday in New York.
excuse.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a note written by your doctor or one of your parents saying that you were ill on a particular day
excuse.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: make up/think up/invent an excuse
I made up some excuse about my car breaking down.
We’d better think up an excuse, fast.
make excuses for somebody/something
His mother was always making excuses for her son's behaviour.
use something as an excuse
She never complained or used her illness as an excuse.
look for an excuse
I began to look for excuses to avoid seeing him.
give an excuse
I'll have to give my boss some kind of excuse.
believe/accept an excuse
She didn’t believe his excuse for one minute.
have an excuse
Companies have no excuse for breaking the law.
a good excuse
A sunny day is a good excuse to go to the beach.
a wonderful excuse
A wedding is a wonderful excuse to buy a new outfit.
a reasonable/plausible excuse
If your train was cancelled, that is a perfectly reasonable excuse.
a legitimate/valid excuse
He didn’t have a legitimate excuse for being late.
the perfect excuse
The phone call gave me the perfect excuse to leave.
a feeble/flimsy/weak excuse
Joe muttered some feeble excuse about having a headache.
a pathetic/lame excuse
That’s the most pathetic excuse I’ve ever heard.
the usual excuse/the same old excuse
He made the usual excuses for not coming.
Whenever the trains are late, it's always the same old excuse.
a convenient excuse
The rioting provided the government with a convenient excuse not to hold an election.
use every excuse in the book
He used every excuse in the book to avoid seeing the doctor.
at the slightest excuse
She comes to our house at the slightest excuse.
